title: Tuesday, 14th June, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:04 am
BE11:04am

Hi, morning, welcome to Markets Live.

BE11:04am

BE11:05am

As you can probably read, that's The Rugby Portobello Trust

11:05 am
BE11:05am

Excellent community charity based in the hinterland between Ladbroke Grove and Shepherds Bush.

BE11:05am

Working hard for what can sometimes feel a rather forgotten bit of London.

BE11:05am

http://www.rugbyportobello.org.uk/

11:05 am
BE11:06am

And as of this morning they're in need of the kind of stuff folk might require after losing their homes to fire.

BE11:06am

Tootbrushes, toiletries, sanitary towels, sweets, biscuits, Coke, nappies, baby food, that kind of thing.

BE11:06am

I don't want to nag or tin rattle. But if you happen to have a few spare quid and an account to Amazon Prime, Ocado, Tesco Direct, whatever, here's the address.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

The Rugby Portobello Trust
221 Walmer Road
London W11 4EY

undefined
BE11:07am

And now, on with the show.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

ROTR, we'll not be doing anything on Gemalto.

BE11:09am

Those who wish to wear that risk are welcome to.

BE11:09am

We covered the ground well enough here, I feel: https://ftalphavil...tslive/2017-05-25/

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Beyond that, I'd note that while rumours are commonplace not all media sources are created equal in how they backtest them.

BE11:10am

Best of luck to all holders.

undefined
11:11 am
BE11:11am

As to London, we have one of those broad and narrow rallies. Everything's up, but not by much.

BE11:12am

FTSE ahead 0.4% at 7532. I think, though haven't checked, that we're about flat on the week now.

BE11:12am

And the fallers are, as always, where the interest lies.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Starting with Ashtead.

Ashtead Group PLC (AHT:LSE): Last: 1,553, down 47 (-2.94%), High: 1,599, Low: 1,550, Volume: 1.17m
BE11:13am

This is UBS arguing that the Trump bump's gotten ahead of itself.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

US construction is looking better, but not enough to justify Ashtead's valuation.

BE11:14am

(Which I make at 13x forward, which isn't aggressively expensive, but what do I know?)

BE11:15am

We continue to believe valuation overestimates market acceleration, underestimates capital requirements, and increasingly misses the risks from competition. Strong FY17 results, but no consensus upgrades, saw a muted investor reaction and we see more downside from here: accelerating competition but slowing end markets this summer could leave valuation of 1.8x EV/IC exposed, and we reiterate Sell.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Within Sunbelt's reported -3% yield for FY17, management disclosed rates were flat (mix a 3% drag). Their outlook is for flat rates in the year ahead but with risks to the upside; we see risks to the downside on two levels: i) recent UBS data suggests rental supply could accelerate in a market which is already expanding, while we expect construction to slow - industry rates could be under pressure by Q3; ii) Sunbelt's c15% pricing premium today may fall: daily/weekly are greater than 25% above prior peaks but local SMEs are likely investing in new fleet while Sunbelt's is ageing (+2mths in FY17), and competition is fierce for longer-term rentals (where pricing is still below prior peaks).

BE11:16am

Ashtead remains very well-run as management aims to balance growth and returns – but we believe it will be difficult to deliver on both fronts, at the same time, to the degree valuation demands. The first priority remains organic growth, and YTD trends remain strong (same-day rental growth in May +15% vs. +14% in Q4; physical utilisation is at record levels, but we note this correlates to mix of longer rentals). Our forecasts see ND/EBITDA at 1.5x by the end of FY18e, but more M&A is likely – however some of this (e.g. Pride) replaces organic growth rather than is accretive, and in general will be a drag on ROIC. We see FY18e ROIC of 11.5%, -40bps y/y.

BE11:16am

We update for results and see EBITDA forecasts reduce 2-3% on slightly lower growth and drop-through estimates; however, lowering capex as a result we see lower depreciation and interest charges and EPS estimates actually rise 2-4%. Our 1,400p PT is based on ROIC using an EV/IC valuation; we expect continued ROIC decline in FY18e.

11:16 am
BE11:17am

Fairly sure Ashtead's a consensus buy across the sellside so that lind of call's quite aggressive.

undefined
BE11:17am

Still in industrial, there's GKN.

11:18 am
BE11:19am

The subject of one of those exclusive-to-all bid rumours last year, of course. Then nothing happened. https://www.ft.com...-9ac1-1055824ca907

GKN PLC (GKN:LSE): Last: 350.30, down 4.8 (-1.35%), High: 352.40, Low: 347.80, Volume: 2.24m
BE11:19am

This morning we get a downgrade from Sanjay Jha, now of Panmure.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

You might remember Sanjay's work through the crisis when he was at Pali International. His good reputation's been earned.

BE11:21am

And, typically, the argument on GKN is a lot broader than the average "it's looking expensive" stuff. He's talking sub-prime 2.0.

BE11:22am

And how the auto loans side is due a rather sharp correction.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Which is a theme we've talked about a lot here. As in, cheap credit and PPI supporting ridiculously high new-car volumes that shorten the cycle for used car volumes and etc etc.

BE11:23am

Here's Panmure.

BE11:23am

Expectations of double-digit growth in 2017 PBT and EPS are looking increasingly optimistic to us given the headwinds in US automotive and Middle East aircraft markets. While GKN has invested heavily in higher-value and next generation products since the 2008 crisis, its profitability is still vulnerable to sudden changes in output. We are now forecasting 2017 PBT and EPS of £666m and 30.1p, around 6% and 10% below mean consensus, respectively. With the stock looking fully valued at 8.7x 2017 EBITDA, we expect a period of underperformance as consensus expectations are cut. We move our recommendation to SELL (HOLD).

11:22 am
BE11:23am

Is North America Driveline (15% of 2016 sales) facing another subprime crisis? In the 2009 credit crunch, North American vehicle output suffered a 32% decline. While we are not forecasting a severe credit crunch, trends in new car sales, used car prices and loan terms imply that the US auto output is likely to experience a double-digit correction shortly. Thanks to fall in interest rates and lengthening loan terms, the auto loans market has been propping up the growth in US new car sales since 2009. However, rising interest rates since the beginning of 2016 have arrested growth in outstanding auto loans and annualised rate of new car sales in May were 10% below the cycle peak in December 2016. In Q1/17, the percentage of trade-ins on new vehicle sales that had negative equity reached a record 33% and the continuing fall in used car prices will only exacerbate this. Average loan terms on new cars have risen to 68 months and it is hard to see how much more this could pull forward sales. China's car market is also suffering a lean spell, with sales falling for the second month in May due to higher taxes.

BE11:23am

Will Qatar crisis prove to be the final straw that reverses Middle East fleet expansion? The decision by the Saudi-led alliance to suspend all air travel to Qatar is adding to the wide-body overcapacity in the Mid-East region. We expect capex plans to be reviewed given the pressure on state budgets due to low oil prices. The Middle East airlines account for 10% and 8% of the Boeing and Airbus unfulfilled order-book. We believe that Emirates’ unfulfilled order for 48 A380s is most vulnerable, but investors should also be prepared for delays/cancelations to B777, B787 and A350 programmes. Qatar Airways, which has 18% excess capacity due to sanctions, is the launch customer for A350.

undefined
11:25 am
BE11:25am

Wow, comments slow today.

BE11:26am

And those we have are straying into areas we'd rather avoid. ROTR: using our pixels to talk about other media is a bit awkward. Can you knock it off, ta?

BE11:26am

Anyway, to the risers, and .....

11:26 am
Centrica PLC (CNA:LSE): Last: 201.00, up 4 (+2.03%), High: 201.20, Low: 197.50, Volume: 11.13m
BE11:26am

Now this is just straight-up weird.

BE11:27am

https://www.thesun...cabinet-ministers/

11:27 am
BE11:27am

The Sun's redoubtable Steve Hawkes writes:

BE11:27am

THERESA MAY is preparing to ditch radical plans for an energy price cap as she dumps ‘toxic’ policies from her disastrous manifesto, sources claimed tonight.
The Sun can reveal Cabinet Ministers have told the PM to axe her flagship proposal for an “absolute” cap on gas and electricity prices from the Queen’s Speech to appease Tories worried about going to war with business.
The PM is instead preparing to outline a big investment in smart meters to deliver greater competition and bring bills down.
One source said: “We have to get back to our free market roots.”

BE11:28am

This is odd.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

I mean, it's probably right because Steve doesn't get much wrong. But it's odd.

BE11:28am

The price cap was a Tory manifesto pledge that had cross-party support.

BE11:28am

Now the Tories plan to ditch it because it's not Tory enough?

11:28 am
BE11:28am

You'll remember that May launched the price cap idea via a Sun op-ed. So it'd have a neat symmetry if it was rolled back via Sun "sources".

BE11:29am

Politics is fascinating.

BE11:29am

Here's JP Morgan Caz

11:29 am
BE11:29am

CMA head Roger Witcomb made headlines in The Times with claims that if a price cap is introduced it could be impossible to remove. The logic goes that if the cap is set too high it won’t have any impact on customers as it won’t reduce bills by much. Set too low and competition will collapse as market prices converge on the cap.
What strikes us as missing here is the magnitude of the detriment – is it possible to introduce a cap which saves a lot of consumers on their annual bills but does not impede competition?

BE11:29am

Previously we would have said no, but on closer examination it appears to us that the extent of the gap between standard variable tariffs (SVTs) and market offers is sufficiently wide enough to reduce bills without impeding competition. Telecom Plus provided us with a useful snapshot of the market yesterday, which shows a time series of average SVTs and the cheapest tariff in the market. While the gap has closed in the past 12 months, it recently started to widen again and remains elevated.

BE11:29am

The second point to note is that if the PPM precedent is anything to go by, a cap on SVT bills will be by definition temporary in nature – there appears to be no appetite to permanently regulate the UK supply market.
Assuming a commitment to smart meters remains both caps will be removed in 2020. A prevailing gap between default tariffs and market prices has taken many years to emerge, with a reversal immediately after the cap is lifted very unlikely.

11:29 am
SSE PLC (SSE:LSE): Last: 1,495, up 4.5 (+0.30%), High: 1,504, Low: 1,490, Volume: 1.54m
National Grid PLC (NG.:LSE): Last: 1,019, up 1.22 (+0.12%), High: 1,023, Low: 1,016, Volume: 2.89m
Telecom Plus PLC (TEP:LSE): Last: 1,218, up 17 (+1.42%), High: 1,230, Low: 1,207, Volume: 51.81k
11:30 am
undefined
BE11:31am

Hexagon mentioned on the right, post the WSJ hitting publish.

BE11:32am

It's been around, this one. Rumoured around the usual channels. But that's not to take anything away from WSJ for getting comfortable enough with the story to be able to publish.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

The gist of which is in talks over a sale to a US or European rival, in a deal valuing the company at ~$20bn.

BE11:33am

Parachutes are that talks are at an early stage and the company may not decide to pursue a sale.

BE11:04am

As is tradition, we start with a picture.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Hexagon response statement this morning is rather nuanced.

BE11:34am

Hexagon regularly evaluates various opportunities to optimise the company’s positioning and shareholder value. Should these evaluations lead to concrete results, the market will be immediately informed.

BE11:35am

Which is as close as you can get to, "confirm" without actually saying "confirm".

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Here's what RBC makes of it all.

BE11:35am

Attractive asset, although perhaps a short list of potential buyers. We have long considered Hexagon an attractive takeout target, albeit a large one,
for many of the global industrials owing to its strong positions in sensors and software. We view this as necessary for capturing and monetising the
growth potential of the Industrial internet of things. While the Industrial IoT is much discussed, concrete examples of how this has helped drive
growth and returns in the sector are harder to find. The size of the deal likely leaves a reasonably short list of potential buyers, with the likes of GE,
ABB, Siemens and Atlas Copco all having come up in our discussions with investors in the past. Software peers could also be potential buyers,
although we’d expect that this would be a smaller list owing to a smaller number of sizeable peers that we think would also find Hexagon’s hardware
exposure (~40%) attractive. That being said, we would not rule out competitive tension, given the relatively unique nature and size of Hexagon.

BE11:35am

Potential price appears attractive. A ~$20bn offer for the shares (assuming the article is not referring to an EV) represents ~ SEK 480 per share, a 27%
premium to last night’s closing price, and a 2018 EV/EBITDA and PE of ~18x and 24x, respectively. These multiples are relatively rich in an industrial
context, although less so when compared to software peers.

11:35 am
BE11:36am

he shares are currently trading up 14% (0900 BST), clearly factoring in some chance of a bid. Recall that there is some – difficult to quantify –
overhang from the CEO’s trial, due to begin in October. The reports and the share price reaction today could simply be seen as removing this
overhang, by presenting a clear alternative should the trial outcome be unfavourable and Hexagon’s key-man is unable to continue his role. We
expect the shares to keep some of the ‘take-out premium’ for the foreseeable future. Further developments in the next few days may however be unlikely; the senior management team are in attendance at Hexagon’s annual conference HxGN LIVE in Las Vegas this week, where the CEO gave his opening keynote speech yesterday evening.

BE11:36am

Cracking timing for the story to land, when all senior and mid management are at the Venetian.

BE11:36am

http://hxgnlive.com/2017

11:37 am
BE11:38am

Must've made for an interesting mood in Delmonico's Steakhouse last night.

BE11:38am

Here's JP Morgan as well.

BE11:38am

Who could be buyers? We think a number of industrials companies could potentially be interested – for example GE, ABB, Schneider, Siemens, etc. In addition, parts or divisions of Hexagon could be of interest to smaller competitors in the metrology, geospatial or CAD/PLM software space. Such competitors include: in metrology: Carl Zeiss, Faro, Mitutoyo, Renishaw. In geosystems equipment: Trimble and Topcon, and GIS mapping: ESRI, Google, and others. In CAP/PLM and BIM: Aveva, Bentley, Autodesk, Dassault, Siemens. None of the companies as potential buyers we mention here have formally commented on their interest, to our knowledge.

11:39 am
BE11:40am

ABB, Schneider and Siemens could potentially be interested in Hexagon, or parts of it, in our view. None of the companies have commented about a potential interest. Strategically, parts of Hexagon could be of interest to all three (and other non-European automation companies). Automation companies could be interested in Industrial Enterprise Solutions (IES, ~50% of company). Siemens is already a market leader in CAD/CAM. The stationary sensors business supplies products for robotics for example. These companies could also be interested in the asset management and services businesses. With 31% of sales in power & energy, 26% in manufacturing and electronics, 25% in automotive and 18% in aerospace and defence, there is a good end-market overlap. Schneider had made an offer, which later was abandoned, for Aveva which has overlap with Hexagon’s PPM but the Industrial Enterprise offering of Hexagon is much broader and beyond what Schneider had stated as an area of potential interest in the past (process simulation and design). Siemens is already a market leader in CAD/CAM and has largely built out its offering in industrial software, indicating in the past that it has a full offering now. Its recent alliance with Bentley Systems covers some of the aspects that IES provides in simulation. ABB has mentioned industrial software as a potential area of interest for acquisitions in the past but we would see limited synergies for a relatively sizable share of sales of Hexagon in GES and parts of IES given ABB’s focus on process industries. For all three, the interest into Geospatial Enterprise Solutions (GES, ~50% of company) would be more limited, particularly in the surveying, mapping, public safety and positioning business where we see limited synergies with their industrial operations. Less than 20% of sales of GES here are in core end-markets for ABB, Schneider and Siemens. Financially, at the speculated $20bn valuation, this would be a very sizable deal, likely having to involve equity financing for all three buyers. Siemens is at the upper end of its maximum leverage target following a number of acquisitions in recent years. ABB has recently announced the acquisition of the B&R deal and for now temporarily suspended its buyback but is close to debt free by the end of this year (net debt, JPME) with close to $5bn in EBITDA (JPME) and hence still has substantial firepower. Schneider has publicly said that it is focusing on add-on acquisitions in the core of its operations with an expected net debt/EBITDA of 0.8x by the end of this year (JPME).

BE11:42am

(@Groundhog Day: for all M&A stories we have a lot of conversations in an attempt to triangulate the risk of pubbing something that's not accurate. It's a difficult balance and very rarely involves any single specific thing.)

BE11:43am

(@Dutchbrat: Bouchon is the only halfway-decent restaurant in the Venetian.)

11:43 am
undefined
BE11:44am

On Aveva, it seems to be the Schneider speculation coming back.

AVEVA Group PLC (AVV:LSE): Last: 2,053, up 100 (+5.12%), High: 2,068, Low: 1,964, Volume: 117.48k
11:44 am
BE11:45am

There's some Schneider UK launch thing today

BE11:46am

... which Bloomberg Intelligence (?) is using as a hook for the idea that Schneider might re-bid, which is an argument they've been pitching for a while now.

BE11:47am

Anyway, looks like speculation rather than rumour. We've not heard anything whatsoever to suggest talks are back on.

11:47 am
undefined
BE11:48am

What else? There's a bit of result stuff to get through.

BE11:48am

WH Smith, for instance.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Usual story really. Travel franchise gouging compensates for death of the high street.

BE11:49am

High Street sales -4%, LFL -4% and flat space contribution.

BE11:49am

Travel sales were up 8% -- LFL +5%, new space +1% and FX up 2%.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Gross margin and cost savings on track. All reassuring really.

BE11:50am

Cost savings still coming through, at the expense of the woeful state of their carpets. High Street margin c. +130bp, Travel c. +90bp for the FY.

BE11:50am

No change to guidance, no terrorism impact, travel slightly subdued due to a shortage of new openings that's just a timing issue.

11:50 am
WH Smith PLC (SMWH:LSE): Last: 1,777, up 33 (+1.89%), High: 1,781, Low: 1,727, Volume: 149.39k
BE11:51am

(@CommentGoesHere: isn't there a story that Mr WH Smith was a smoker who walked around various cities and, wherever he hit a point where he needed a packet of gaspers, he opened a shop? I'm probably misremembering that or becoming confused, as happens at my age.)

BE11:52am

Anyway, here's Cantor to say "it's in the price".

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Our view: Today’s Q3 update is in line with expectations with Travel seeing continued LFL growth driven by self-help measures and rising passenger numbers whilst High Street LFLs are down in a relatively quiet quarter. Gross margin improvements remain in line with plan and costs remain under tight control. We leave forecasts unchanged at this stage with the pre-close update due in late August.

BE11:52am

Q3 Trading Update: Travel LFL +5%, High Street LFL -4% – WH Smith has reported on trading over the 15 weeks to 10th June 2017 (Q3). Over the period Group sales are up by 2%, with LFLs flat. Travel division sales are up by 8% (+6% constant currency) with LFLs up by 5%. This follows LFL growth of +5% in H1 and is against a comp of +3% LY, leaving the two year growth rate at +8% compared to 10% over H1. Management attribute the continued sales growth to their on-going focus on customer service levels, execution and space and category management. The rise in passenger numbers is also a key driver of the growth. Fifteen UK stores are due to open in the current year and the Group has also won a contract to open 6 units in Rome. Gross margins are in line with plan. High Street sales are down 4% with LFLs down by 4% in a relatively quiet quarter. This follows a decline of 3% in H1 and is against a comp of -3% LY, leaving the two year growth rate at -7% compared to -3% over H1. The Post Office opening programme is on track and there are now 165 units within the High Street store estate (vs 162 at H1). Gross margin improvement and cost reductions are in line with plan.

BE11:52am

Forecasts Unchanged – Management indicate they remain confident in the outcome for the full year. Ahead of today consensus PBT stood at £138m (CFE £138m) and we do not expect any major changes today and will review forecasts again following the Q4 update in late August.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Valuation & Recommendation – WH Smith trades on 16.8x cal’17 falling to 15.9x cal’18. The forecast yield is 2.8% rising to 3.8%. The Group remains strongly cash generative and the buyback programme continues to provide EPS progression. The international growth opportunity in the Travel division is clear, and provides a long term growth. We believe that it will become increasingly hard to grow profits in the High Street division through margin management and cost control over the longer term. We retain our HOLD recommendation.

BE11:53am

And something from the sales desk from Northern Trust.

BE11:53am

Solid, if a little unspectacular – though let’s face it, this is not a business that is ever likely to blow the lights out. But it is one we think of as very high quality (metronomic cash returns on, and of, capital). It is also perhaps one of the less obvious routes for exposure to the structural growth in air passengers. And, having drifted somewhat since strong H1 numbers, it remains decidedly cheap we think at a 5.9% forward 12M FCF yield and a just a 6% premium to the market on forward 12M P/E (consensus). Far less ‘dull high street business’, more ‘quality growth’ than you might think. It’s no semiconductor or AV or gaming name…but as long as people fly and buy (overpriced!) snacks in airports, we think this is a stock to buy and tuck away for the long haul.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

To that I'll only add that all our arguments about SSP apply equally to WH Smith. They're operating effective monopolies that pass quite a lot of the benefit of price gouging to railway and airport operators, and it's difficult to see how the consumer benefits.

BE11:55am

Pitch franchise reform and regulation isn't a high-profile risk right now, but if there's a change of government that puts a train enthusiast in charge .... well, who knows?

undefined
11:56 am
BE11:56am

Will just wrap through requests for the remaining five minutes.

BE11:57am

(@Xanthine: thank you. That might well be it. I've started blurring fiction and fact, which given my job is probably not a good state of affairs.)

BE11:57am

St Ives ......

11:57 am
ST Ives PLC (SIV:LSE): Last: 50.06, up 12.56 (+33.48%), High: 52.00, Low: 44.50, Volume: 5.23m
BE11:58am

Everything's going right all of a sudden.

BE11:58am

Strategic Marketing margins and revenue inflect.

11:58 am
BE11:59am

And net debt coming back post property disposals.

BE11:59am

Singer upgrades.

BE11:59am

The key Strategic Marketing business (over 90% of FY18 group EBIT) is trading better than we had expected, leading us to raise our EBIT expectations by £1m. This is driven by a return to a strong level of growth in H2 (7% LFL CER) with noteworthy strength in Digital. Marketing Activation has also traded better than expected with revenues flat in H2 (3% decline in H1) leading us to edge up revenues. At this stage, with a reorganisation underway, a strategic review being conducted and a significant contract renewal in play, we see little point in adjusting profit expectations. Books also appears to be on the stronger side but we do not make any changes ahead of the reorganisation program completion, although we flag it is on track. Overall we are very encouraged by progress. The trading update, property disposal and improved debt profile show the way forward. In the near term we look for another property disposal (N1Se c£4-5m), clarity on the triennial review and in due course the potential of Marketing Activation to be sold once the reorganisation and contract renewal are out of the way. With news flow much more positive and the share price having slipped below 40p the risk/reward profile has become more attractive. Our “low” case SOTP valuations for FY17 and FY18 are 69p and 78p respectively (an FY18 “Medium” case SOTP is c100p). Allowing for a further risk discount and a Target Price of 60p (65% potential 12month TSR) the stock easily warrants a Buy, hence we upgrade. Further disposals would improve sentiment and focus significantly and would likely drive the share price into three figures.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

As does Arden, but I can't find that one in my email right now.

undefined
BE11:59am

And Bellway.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Usual story of a housebuilder being isolated from the underlying market thanks to the distortion caused by Help To Buy in a market starved of volume.

Bellway PLC (BWY:LSE): Last: 2,977, up 127 (+4.46%), High: 2,980, Low: 2,900, Volume: 435.53k
BE12:01pm

Average sales per week (private and social) up 13%

12:01 pm
BE12:02pm

Modest slowdown from previously, but that's expected.

BE12:04pm

Heh, my PC keyboard just died. Had to swap it over live.

BE12:04pm

First time that's happened in a decade of doing this nonsense.

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

Have some sellside on Bellway and then let's close.

BE12:05pm

Numis incoming.

BE12:05pm

Bellway's trading update shows a double digit rise in reservations, strong and improved margins and a solid backdrop in terms of land and forward sales to support further growth in 2018. We upgrade 2017 and 2018 PBT estimates by 3% and 4% and still think that forecasts are set at a cautious level and the risk remains on the upside. Despite all these attractions and top-quartile returns the shares continue to lag the sector on valuation which we feel is completely unwarranted.

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

We think these forecasts are well supported by the strong order book which is up 6.4%
to £900m (and 70% contracted) and Bellway’s strong operational disciplines which
have helped it regain its 5* HBF rating despite significant volume growth. Since we
first released 2017 estimates (in June 2014) we have upgraded PBT estimates by
53%, versus the sector average upgrade of 16%. Looking forward Bellway should see
strong progress in outlet numbers through 2018 (with all land in place with detailed
consent after high levels of investment over the past few years) and therefore if market
conditions remain unchanged we should see further strong volume/profit progress.

BE12:05pm

Despite Bellway’s strong growth and returns (we estimate a 20.5% ROE on closing
equity in 2017) the shares are trading on 1.32x P/NTAV, 6.9x PE and a yield of
5.3% (which is 3x covered for Dec). This is a material discount to the sector which
we believe is unwarranted. Whilst Bellway's yield is slightly below the sector this is
due to management looking to reinvest in land/WIP at high returns and maintain a
strong balance sheet. However, if market conditions were not supportive of this growth
Bellway could quickly switch to a cash return model given its prudent gearing, low land
creditors and strong land position which would boost the dividend materially (2x cover
in Dec 2018 would equate to a yield of 7.3%).

undefined
12:06 pm
BE12:07pm

Okay, so that'll do. Let's go for a walk.

BE12:07pm

(Not together, obviously. That'd be awful.)

BE12:07pm

See you back here tomorrow.

12:07 pm
BE12:07pm

Afternoon all.

BE11:34am

This is on the back of the insider trading case against CEO Ola Rollen and the ill-health of Melker Schorling, who has more than a quarter of the shares and nearly half of the voting rights.
